comments.commentBody:
Smith alum here. The disturbing part of all this is not transgender students in particular, but that gender issues have been made such a large part of public discourse at women's colleges, to the extent that students cannot express traditional views without fear of repercussion. That is not the (mostly) tolerant atmosphere I remember. We had our individual problems with race, religion, and social status, but overall tolerance reigned.

I'm considering cutting back my legacy to Smith due to inability of the college at times to maintain a civil atmosphere, such as the Lagarde debacle last spring. Very disappointing.
Let's also add unfettered access to guns and restrictions on voting.

Ebola is not a serious threat to the vast majority of Americans. But the loss of health care is. Pollution of the air is. Contamination of beef is. Shoddily produced cars is. Drunken drivers is. Texting while driving certainly is. The flu might be.

Too bad CNN doesn't sent Anderson Cooper out to monitor the real threats to our health and safety. But that just wouldn't be exciting enough to bring up the ratings!!!
A travel ban is hardly the same thing as grounding all flights!

My mistake. Larry king has had four times as many divorces, not two times, than there have been people that have contracted Ebola in the U.S. To be clear 8 divorces, 2 Ebola US cases. My apologies to Larry King.

The one travel case we had, Mr. Duncan, ended with his death and at least two infected health workers. I believe the Hospital claimed to use CDC compliant protocols.

A danger of an infectious disease is that it can grow exponentially. If each paitent infects two more, as occured with Mr. Duncan, the number of cases doubles with each generation of infections 1, +2, +4 ... +1024 and this would be very dangerous.

If we wish to act with an "abundance of caution" we must start with policies that would not allow the same thing to occur. It must go beyond survey questions and temperature readings that proved ineffective in his case. I so no alternative to mandatory quarantine upon return from hot zones. Britain has banned travel and has had no traveler related infections.

My mother' sister died of Scarlett fever when my mother was in first grade in the early 1930's. The city of Buffalo, quarantined my mothers family for a year. They only allowed my grandfather out to go to work. The 4 surviving kids and my grandmother were stuck in the house with no TV and they did not understand English ( so no Radio). My mother and her 3 rd grade brother had to repeat a grade in school. Her other two sisters were babies.

I remember being quarantined when I was nine years old because my sister had scarlet fever, then quarantine-able at least in New Haven, Connecticut. It was a 21-day sentence of isolation. But after 14 of those days I came down with scarlet fever, and we had to start another 21 days of quarantine. Our poor mother!

There was no television, but there were soap operas just about all day long on the radio, and I listened to those from morning till late afternoon when the programs for kids came on. My parlor trick, when we were finally released from our solitary confinement, was to recite the daily radio schedule to any grown-up willing to listen to me.
Joy Kaiser, Palo Alto, CA

I have been thinking the same. It worries me to see the nurses' pictures, huge close up shots, flashing constantly across our tv screens. I pray they recover and are lauded as heroes for their brave work. But I also fear for their personal safety when they are released from the hospital.

I'm not sure I understand you, as I recall, our response to AIDS was extremely slow, ineffective  and stigmatizing - we should have been much more, not less, concerned.  Initial response to Ebola has shown US hospitals grossly unprepared to deal with a serious contagious disease, in terms of diagnosis, treatment, and management of those in contact with the sick person.  We should have protocols in place that allow for full salary payment plus bonus of those quarantined as well as tracking of their travel - not to mention giving them grocery deliver and laundry service. Someone who has simply "traveled to Liberia" and not worked with sick people may be being dramatic about their risk, but a nurse who has cleaned up vomit & diarrhea from a victim without proper protocol is certainly at high risk and should not have been allowed to travel or even get out of their house.   Local responders need training not simply on how to deal with Ebola but how to identify those at risk and what specialists to contact if they have a question.  Ebola is probably not 'the big one" for the US, but we will have a big one and when it hits we had better have the systems in place to deal with it. It is the big one for West Africa, however, and that indicates that need to be concerned as nat'l policy about what goes on it other countries.

How about no travel to or from Texas?

Wake up, Phil!

Africa is a continent not a country. There are 54 countries in Africa. Ebola has only occurred in about 5 or 6 of them. Senegal (one of those where Ebola occurred) has been declared Ebola Free by WHO. Nigeria will most likely be declared Ebola Free on Monday.

Three people turned up with Ebola in Texas, which is three more than in Egypt, South Africa, or Somalia combined, but ok, shut down Africa and not Texas.

Don't you have some Muppets to make fun of ?
No travel to or from Africa is a minimum requirement at his point. Wake up Obama!
Grow up, big guy.

This article is like propaganda. It attacks people who might have a different opinion from the government. It says if you're afraid of a deadly disease you're an hysteric and maybe even bigoted. We're supposed to say boo hoo for the poor quarantined people because it's all unnecessary. But trained nurses and doctors keep getting sick and dying, despite official pronouncements that the disease does not spread easily.

The spread of deadly Ebola is inconsistent with the vision of One World, some borderless Utopia - gee, what a drag, so we'll pretend it doesn't exist. The President refuses to do what need to be done, restrict foreign travel and impose a quarantine on returning citizens.

I feel like no one is looking out the public.

It is one very serious concern about quarantines. You want people who may be sick to go to the doctor. If they cannot afford the loss of income from potential quarantine, some infected people will not seek help and will go on to infect others.

Contact tracing is crucial to stopping this. If people are afraid to go to the doctor or hospital, contact tracing will break down.

With a GDP of $3 billion, it is unlikely that we will have a halt to the global economy if we quarantine Liberia. We can feed the entire nation with a rounding error in our GDP. If this thing escapes then you will have an economic problem.

We are not a "Christian" nation.  We are a nation of  many religions.   I think the American people, be they religious, atheistic or agnostic, have the ability to be rational, compassionate, cooperative and courageous, in an emergency, such as the Ebola crisis.  Consider our history of solving enormous problems.

Unfortunately, the situation is as Bruni describes it. And he definitely is not Douthat of Brooks.

Let's review the basic facts. There has not been an epidemic of any serious disease in the US for decades - the last one was most likely polio more than eighty years ago.

There was sex related AIDS epidemic in selected communities that has not spread outside these communities and now HIV infection is under a good control thanks to the excellent work of our pharmaceutical industry. No drastic measures (quarantine) were ever justified.

Ebola, however, is very different. It is not as deadly as ancient epidemics of bubonic plague or smallpox but deadly enough.

We were completely unprepared to deal with it in an efficient way - nobody alive today remembers anything like that.

Hence the tolerance of arbitrary trips of exposed workers who may have spread the disease to hundreds of people around them.

This is, obviously, not an attempt to excuse the president. Even people like myself (I am 80 years old) do not remember epidemics except during the early years of AIDS. And the protection then (and now) was simple: use condoms.

Ebola has nothing to do with sex and condoms are useless. People have to use protection common only in the space walks.

Will this Bruni's article wake up our president? Maybe he is just waking up and may finally order some rather drastic measures..

Very, very disappointing last two years for all of us who voted for him.

I would hardly classify myself as a libertarian, but if you think through the consequences of a home delivery crystal meth or heroin service outs hard to find fault with the core idea.  The legal problems with the drug trade have always revolved around the issue with connecting the manufacturer with the end user.

You're representing a whole country, the United States, and labeling everyone in the same fashion you accuse a frightened minority of doing. We are not all sitting in fear and ignorance, but are as much at a loss as to how a potential pandemic can be avoided in this very populous nation. Ebola is a non discriminating killer. Turning this into political fodder about the oppression of dark skinned people is as vile as what you are accusing the others of doing.

Yes, they let people into the US from West Africa who have probably been exposed to Ebola and yet citizens of the US who have possibly been exposed to Ebola cannot take public transportation or visit public places.  Go figure
There are no straight flights from any of those countries into the US.  What 10 hr flight are you taking about?

It is easy to tell who has come from West Africa.  People must have passports and visas to get into this country.  If they are American citizens, they have to have visas or at least stamps when entering a foreign country.  So, it should not matter where the plane departed from or how many different airplanes one took to get to the US

All this resulting from ONE infected person (Mr. Duncan) entering the United States.  But we let 150 additional persons into the U.S. from the three Ebola-stricken countries EVERY DAY.  Why not require a 21-day quarantine BEFORE someone who has been in one of those countries can board a flight to the U.S.?  Does it really make sense to take their temperature after they get off a 10-hour flight packed in with 280 other people?  What are we going to do if they have it?  Track down all 280 people who were on the flight ... AND their families?

You can thank Texas and Privatized Medicine for this bungling. Texas is one of the States that did not approve Medicaid for all. Texas has one of the highest percentages of uninsured residents. So no insurance, standard operating procedure give you some Tylenol to bring a fever down and send them home with a prescription for antibiotics. Then when he came back they put him in an 8 person Ward for the uninsured patients.

Then we hear from the non- union nurses who have been threatened that They will loose their jobs if they talk to the media; that their was no training just an e-mail and a posting in the break room on the stuff from the CDC. No you are suppose to pay people for training not post it for optional reading in the break room. When do nurses get breaks in a non- union environment.

It is not true. WHO worked with Nigeria and Senegal to develop their protocols and the recommended isolation period was 21 days. On the WHO website, it says the incubation period for Ebola is 2 - 21 days.

However for a country to be officially declared Ebola Virus free, WHO uses twice the incubation period of 42 days (2 * 21)

Excuse me but is it true or not that the WHO has designated the quarantine time for potential symptom identification as 42 days and not 21? Great article but , exactly who are we to believe on this. Rachel Maddow did a great opening segment on the disease. It was educational. Perhaps if more facts were disseminated to the public at large we would better know how to be proactive to this scourge.
Pic.

I was aware there was a theme, but didn't know what it was until I read the blog. I admire the construction but found the puzzle solving experience exciting in places and a slog in others.

By the end, I just wanted to finish and get back to my book.

Richard, you republicans lack the same qualities that are lacked by the corporations which have been given personhood by the most activist court in memory. The qualities to which I allude are a heart and a soul. You folks  deny food stamps to the poor in order to subsidize wealthy agriculturists. You deny healthcare and Medicaid to millions of citizens in the red states that would cost the same states little or nothing.  With the compliance of a blind court majority that denies the existence of racism, every red state greeted that decision by establishing racist and exclusionary voting legislation designed to discourage certain citizens who generally vote left. The republicans support only their corporate masters epitomized by the Brothers Koch and Walmart which pays its employees so handsomely that they are forced to resort to food stamps and Medicaid. The majority of poor people in this country are women with children , the elderly, and the disabled. The myth that multitudes of able bodied people are on the dole is pure nonsense. And what would you do with the needy, Richard ? Finish them off by slow starvation and lack of medical care ? Shoot them ? Your position, like that of all republicans, seems to be that you have yours and later for everyone else. It reeks of selfishness, condescension, and a huge lack of common human decency.

If travel to a certain place is illegal, only illegal people (or people engaging in illegal activities) will travel there. And travel there they WILL do.

This logic should be understandable to many republicans as it's similar to their arguments against gun control. Remember how only the criminals have guns?

People are not talking about harm to the economies of poor African nations out of altruism. If we lose control of who is traveling where, this thing will definitively get away from us. We have to be able to track people's movements in and out of infected areas.
It is you who are hyperbolic. I don't agree with your characterization of Americans.

I feel pretty sure the nurse who flew believed she was not seriously at risk. I think she called in to the CD that morning mainly b/c she she didn't want to get in trouble for breaking protocol.

Let's remember, it takes a fair amount of either courage or denial - believing it can't happen to you - to go into an Ebola patient's room in the first place.

HUGE THANK YOU to the nurses.
Couldn't agree with you more. You summed it up perfectly.
